content: The Act may be cited as the "Securing our Secrets Act" or the "SOS Act". Definitions are provided in Section 2. In this Act, "appropriate congressional committees" refer to specific committees in the Senate and House of Representatives. The term "Department" means the Department of State. "Infraction" and "violation" are defined as per Executive Order 13526. The "Inspector General" refers to the Inspector General for the Department of State. The term "violation" is defined according to Executive Order 13526. The term "Inspector General" refers to the Inspector General for the Department of State and the Broadcasting Board of Governors. The term "intelligence community" is defined as per the National Security Act of 1947. The term "Secretary" refers to the Secretary of State. SEC. 3. USE OF NONGOVERNMENTAL INFORMATION SYSTEMS. Employees of the Department must use only Department-owned electronic communication systems for work-related communications. The Secretary must certify annually that all employees have access to these systems. The Secretary must certify annually that all Department employees have access to electronic communication systems. If certification cannot be made, a report must be submitted to congressional committees detailing the number of employees without access, reasons for the lack of access, and steps taken to address it. The Secretary of State must certify annually that all Department employees have access to electronic communication systems. If certification cannot be made, a report must be submitted to congressional committees detailing the reasons for lack of access, steps taken to ensure access, and measures for recording and reviewing work-related electronic communications for classified information. The Secretary may waive requirements for up to 10 employees with written certification to congressional committees. The Secretary of State can waive requirements for up to 10 employees if it is in the foreign policy or national security interest of the United States, with the condition that all work-related written communications will be properly archived. The Secretary of State can waive requirements for up to 10 employees for 180 days if it is in the foreign policy or national security interest of the United States, with proper justification to congressional committees. Multiple waivers can be issued if consistent with certification and justification. The Inspector General will develop an oversight plan within 90 days to ensure compliance with the requirements of the Act by the Secretary and Department employees. SEC. 4. REPORT ON SECURITY REVIEWS AND VIOLATIONS. The Secretary must submit an annual report to Congress detailing security violations, including unauthorized transfer of classified information, with information on the responsible employee, date, and description of each violation. The annual report to Congress must include details of security violations, such as the employee's name, violation date, description, applicable laws violated, and actions taken by the Department in response, including disciplinary measures and remedial training. The annual report to Congress must include details of security violations, such as employee names, violation dates, laws violated, and Department actions taken. The report must also include information on any additional security violations by the same employee in the past 10 years, with justifications for not terminating the employee or involving the FBI. Additionally, the report must be kept private and transmitted securely to protect information under the Privacy Act of 1974. SEC. 5. CLASSIFIED INFORMATION SPILLAGE. The Secretary appoints officials for training in detecting classified information spillage. Randomized sampling of emails is conducted quarterly to detect spillage among employees with security clearances. The Inspector General audits the Department's program for detecting classified information spillage and includes findings in semiannual reports to congressional committees. SEC. 6. REMEDIAL TRAINING. Emergency Refresher Training: The Secretary must certify that all Department personnel with security clearances have completed training on handling classified information, including rules for electronic communication and derivative classification. It also mentions the requirements under Executive Order 13526 regarding declassification and the responsibilities of the Secretary. The requirements of Executive Order 13526 include optimizing sharing of classified information, designating a senior agency official, penalties for violations, and a signed certification by employees after receiving training. Employees with security clearances must undergo retraining to ensure they understand the rules and responsibilities of accessing national security information. The training includes penalties for violations and a commitment to comply with all regulations. The Secretary prioritizes emergency refresher training for employees with Top Secret clearances first, followed by those with lower levels of clearance. Employees with security clearances must undergo retraining in a specific order based on their clearance level. The Secretary has the authority to delay emergency refresher training for up to 30 days for certain employees or groups if it is deemed necessary for critical foreign policy interests, with notification to congressional committees. The Secretary can delay emergency refresher training for up to 30 days for certain employees or groups if it is necessary for critical foreign policy interests. Applicable rules and procedures include federal statutes, Executive Orders, executive orders on classified information, the Foreign Affairs Manual, and Departmental guidance. SEC. 7. ENDURING TRAINING PROGRAM TO PREVENT MISHANDLING OF INTELLIGENCE INFORMATION. The Secretary must establish a training program for all Department employees on preventing the transfer of classified information to unauthorized systems. SEC. 8. PLAN FOR REFORMING RESPONSE TO REQUESTS FOR INFORMATION AND INFORMATION ARCHIVING. The Secretary must submit a plan within 90 days for completing reforms related to identifying classified information in documents subject to FOIA requests. This plan includes developing a training program for Department employees in coordination with the Director of National Intelligence. The Secretary must submit a plan within 90 days for completing reforms related to identifying classified information in documents subject to FOIA requests. This includes developing a training program for Department employees on archiving emails and electronic communications in accordance with relevant laws. The plan includes developing a training program for Department officials on archiving emails and electronic communications in compliance with relevant laws. It also mandates an annual sworn affidavit from employees certifying proper document archiving. The Inspector General will report to congressional committees on the Secretary's implementation of the plan for archiving and securing information within one year of the Act's enactment.
